persona.name: Shanice Marie Washington

occupation.title: Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA)
occupation.employment_status: Employed, full-time with occasional overtime and rotating shifts
description: Daily role: provides hands-on patient care — bathing, feeding, turning bedridden patients, collecting vitals, assisting nurses during procedures, and documenting care in the electronic chart.
Typical schedule: three 12-hour shifts per week (mix of day and evening) with some weekend coverage and holiday rotation.
Responsibilities: ensure patient comfort and safety, communicate changes to RNs, support discharges by helping patients prepare and by relaying necessary home-care instructions.
Skills used at work: safe patient transfers, dementia behavior management, basic wound observation and reporting, clear communication with multidisciplinary teams, infection control protocols.

Work environment: busy county hospital with limited staffing; resource constraints mean CNAs often stretch to meet patient needs; Shanice is pragmatic, reliable and frequently asked to train new CNAs.

Challenges: physically demanding, emotionally heavy (witnessing end-of-life care, families in crisis), irregular schedule that complicates steady childcare or long-term education plans (not applicable here, but affects relationships and routines).

Career aspirations: short-term — become a floor lead/CNA mentor; medium-term — complete an LPN program if finances and schedule allow; long-term — move into patient care coordination or community health outreach within the hospital system.

persona.gender: Cisgender woman (identifies with female assigned at birth)
persona.residence: Atlanta, Georgia (urban neighborhood, rents a 2-bedroom apartment in a long-established African American community)

details: Associate of Applied Science in Medical Assisting, Atlanta Technical College (2010)
Continuing education: 16 hours/year in dementia care, infection control, and patient lifting/transfer safety
Several non-credit community courses: basic bookkeeping, smartphone troubleshooting class from local library, and a six-week meal-prep/cost-saving nutrition workshop run by a neighborhood nonprofit

long_term_goals: To be financially stable enough to move out of renting and buy a modest single-family home in her neighborhood or a nearby suburb within 7–10 years.
To achieve a supervisory position (CNA lead or patient care coordinator) at the hospital and complete a comp-time/accrued leave policy-friendly schedule.
To maintain strong ties with her mother and extended family and help younger nieces/nephews with school and life choices.
To remain active in her church and eventually lead a small outreach program providing meals and basic health screenings in her community.
To be healthy and reduce her reliance on processed foods — consistently lower her blood pressure and improve stamina so she can keep working physically demanding shifts into older age.
To save for retirement, even modestly, and leave a small legacy for nieces/nephews (educational assistance or short-term support).

style.general_tone: Warm, direct, and community-grounded. Uses humor and exasperation in roughly equal measure. Speaks with a Southern urban inflection typical of midtown Atlanta: vowel colors and rhythmic phrasing influenced by African American Vernacular English, softened in professional settings.
speech_patterns: Uses colloquial turns of phrase with neighbors and church friends — 'child, I tell you' or 'lawd' — but switches to more neutral, professional phrasing at work.
Laughs openly and often; punctuates stories with short, emphatic exclamations ('You know!') and hand gestures.
Has a measured, calm voice with higher volume when excited; prefers face-to-face conversation and avoids texting for long, complicated issues.
Occasionally uses religious idioms ('blessings', 'thank the Lord') in casual conversation.
Tends to pause when thinking about money or family issues, then becomes very pragmatic and solution-oriented.
mannerisms: Fidgets with a simple gold cross necklace when nervous or thinking.
Counts money or receipts discreetly before making purchases.
Maintains steady eye contact when listening, tilts head slightly to the left when considering what someone says.
Likes to smell tea or coffee before sipping and will describe flavors as a way to connect with people.
Taps her foot to rhythms — commonly hums or offers a line from a gospel hymn while doing chores.
dress_and_grooming: Work: functional scrubs and comfortable sneakers; keeps hair in a low bun or braided styles during shifts.
Off-duty: casual but put-together — jeans, colorful blouses, practical sandals or low boots; wears a favorite church hat or headscarf on Sundays.
Accessories are modest: a small cross necklace, gold hoop earrings, a practical leather wristwatch.
Overall aesthetic: neat, homey, approachable — prioritizes comfort and durability over trends.
communication_preferences: Prefers phone calls for urgent matters, in-person conversation for emotionally fraught topics, and brief texts for confirmations.
Less reliant on social media for personal connection; uses Facebook mainly to follow church and community pages and to keep up with family.

traits: Conscientious: highly responsible, punctual to shifts, and attentive to routines and checklists.
Empathetic: feels strong compassion for patients, particularly older adults and those without family visitors.
Practical: solves problems with straightforward pragmatic steps, values small, achievable wins.
Community-oriented: places a high value on neighborhood ties, church groups, and helping others locally.
Resilient: has weathered financial setbacks and workplace stress without losing hope.
Skeptical of flashy promises: distrusts quick fixes and prefer tried-and-true approaches.
Religiously grounded: faith provides emotional scaffolding and a moral framework.
Financially anxious: worries about bills, budgets, and future stability; tends toward cautious spending.
Warm and sociable: enjoys gatherings, church potlucks, and bingo nights.
Sometimes stubborn: once decided, holds her position and can be slow to change plans if she believes them right.
Protective: fiercely looks out for younger relatives and neighborhood kids.
Low tolerance for injustice: tightens when she perceives unfair treatment, especially regarding healthcare or neighborhood neglect.

big_five.openness: Moderate (55/100) — curious about practical new ideas (better recipes, efficient tools) but conservative about major life changes.
big_five.conscientiousness: High (78/100) — organized in routines, reliable at work, values responsibility.
big_five.extraversion: Moderately High (65/100) — enjoys social contact, church activities, and small gatherings; needs downtime alone after busy days.
big_five.agreeableness: High (72/100) — cooperative, helpful, trusting in close circles, but can be guarded with strangers or institutions.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate (48/100) — experiences worry (primarily about finances and family), occasional mood swings under stress, but generally steady.

interests: Church choir and Sunday service participation
Cooking Southern comfort food with a health-conscious twist
Community volunteer drives (coats, food, health screenings)
Watching college football (follows Georgia games closely) and the Atlanta Hawks
Listening to gospel and classic R&B playlists
Watching medical dramas and docu-style healthcare shows
Attending neighborhood block meetings
Sewing simple mending projects and hemming pants
Budget-friendly meal-prep planning and couponing
Gardening container herbs on her apartment balcony
Listening to talk radio about local issues in the morning
Occasional thrift-store shopping to find good deals
Bingo nights at the church/community center
Learning basic home repair — changing a faucet washer, swapping a light fixture
Participating in community fitness walking groups
Watching YouTube cooking tutorials for healthier sides
Reading local news websites and church newsletter
Taking her mother to medical appointments and advocating when needed
Collecting family recipes (keeps them on index cards in a shoebox)
Hosting small potlucks after church
Organizing simple health info booths — blood pressure checks, flu shot reminders
Attending occasional continuing-education CNA workshops
Offering ride-sharing to neighbors for grocery runs
Keeping a small stash of cash for emergency expenses
Exploring affordable LPN program options online during free time
favorite_foods_and_drinks: Sweet potato pie (family recipe — always a holiday must)
Collard greens cooked with smoked turkey — she reduces salt and swaps in olive oil when possible
Baked chicken seasoned with paprika, garlic, and lemon
Brown rice and black-eyed peas
Cabbage slow-cooked with spices
Cornbread with a dab of honey
Yams with a light sprinkle of cinnamon instead of too much sugar
Black coffee in the morning (preferably brewed at home)
Herbal teas in the evening — chamomile or peppermint
Iced tea (lightly sweetened) at church gatherings
Occasional fast-food fried chicken on payday — a treat, not routine
Homemade stews with lots of root vegetables
Oatmeal with fruit for quick breakfasts on work mornings
Greek yogurt with a little honey and granola as a snack
Peanut butter on whole-wheat toast for quick energy
Fresh fruit from the weekend farmer’s market if on sale
Store-brand frozen vegetables to stretch the grocery budget
Caramel-flavored coffee drinks from the local cafe on special occasions
Canned greens and cornbread mixes kept in pantry for emergencies
Simple, healthy dips for vegetable platters when hosting guests

media_and_technology.screen_time: Moderate — checks phone in the morning and evening, streams shows a few times a week, uses limited social media.
television: Local news in the morning (tune-in for weather and community stories)
Medical dramas (e.g., long-form hospital shows) and occasional game shows
Sundays: live-streamed church services sometimes when she or her mother can't attend in person
streaming: Netflix or Hulu for chosen shows — prefers bingeing one series over sporadic watching
Uses YouTube mainly for how-to videos (cooking, sewing, simple home maintenance)
social_media: Facebook: primary platform, follows family members, church page, community groups
Uses Messenger for family chats and event coordination
Avoids heavy posting; prefers to react and comment on close friends' updates
devices: Android smartphone (mid-range model) used for calls, texts, banking app, and photos
A small laptop used occasionally for community flyers, online class searches, and bill pay
Bluetooth radio in the kitchen for music and local talk radio

fashion_and_appearance_preferences: Prefers breathable fabrics (cotton blends) because of long shifts
Likes a splash of color — coral blouses or teal scarves
Buys durable shoes with arch support for long hours standing
Avoids flashy jewelry at work, keeps a few sentimental pieces for days off
social_preferences: Small gatherings and potlucks over large parties
Prefers people who are punctual and considerate, dislikes chronic lateness
Enjoys multi-generational conversation — comfortable being around elders and kids
Likes volunteering as a way to meet people and build relationships
Values directness and emotional honesty in close friends

beliefs: Healthcare affordability is a very big problem — medical bills and prescription costs regularly disrupt people she knows.
Drug addiction is a very big problem in her community; she believes it needs compassionate treatment options and better access to rehabilitation.
Insurance often fails the most vulnerable — Medicaid gaps and high co-pays are harmful.
Hospitals and clinics should do more community outreach and preventive care.
Faith communities have an important role in offering social support and basic services.
Churches should not be political platforms but should stand up for social justice quietly through service.
Family (extended family included) is a primary source of identity and mutual aid.
Stable work and predictable schedules are as important as pay for quality of life.
Education matters, but rigid college costs make vocational routes (e.g., LPN, CNA) essential and respectable.
People deserve dignity regardless of socioeconomic status — everyone has a story.
Neighbors look out for each other; informal networks are crucial when formal systems fail.
The criminal justice system is uneven; minor drug offenses should be treated as health issues, not only criminal matters.
Local leaders (mayor, council) can make a real difference when they prioritize housing and transit.
Affordable, reliable public transit improves job access and should be expanded.
Renters deserve protections against sudden eviction and unreasonable rent hikes.
Voting matters — local elections can change everyday things like park maintenance, clinic hours, and policing.
Small businesses in the neighborhood are important and should be supported with community patronage.
Public schools need resources for counseling and extracurriculars; afterschool programs keep kids safe and engaged.
There should be more accessible mental health services in community centers and churches.
People should take personal responsibility for health when possible, but systemic barriers limit choices.
Prescription drug prices are excessive; negotiation and generics should be easier to access.
She trusts medical staff she knows personally and is wary of distant bureaucracies.
Vaccination for infectious disease is important — she got vaccinated for COVID and encourages others to do the same, while respecting individual concerns.
Police-community relationships should be rebuilt through accountability, transparency, and community policing models.
She believes in helping people by offering immediate support (food, rides) and connecting them to services rather than shaming them.
Substance use disorder treatments should include job training and housing support, not just detox.
Church outreach combined with health screenings is an effective way to reach older adults who avoid clinics.
Technology is useful but can be isolating; face-to-face contact is still the best way to sustain community.
Youth need structured programs — sports leagues, tutoring, and mentorship reduce risk behaviors.
There is systemic racism affecting job opportunities and health outcomes; acknowledgment and targeted policies are needed.
She believes people can change, and that second chances are important for those who have struggled with addiction or minor offenses.
Social media can spread helpful information but also amplifies rumors — verify before sharing.
Practical, incremental policy changes (expanded Medicaid coverage, tenant protections, community mental health funds) will create real improvement.
skills: Clinical patient care: bathing, feeding, turning and positioning, bed-to-chair transfers, basic wound observation.
Vitals collection and documentation: BP, pulse, temperature, respiratory rate, weight.
Dementia care techniques: redirection, calm presence, routine establishment to reduce agitation.
Basic CPR and first aid (certified and recertified every two years).
Electronic charting: comfortable inputting notes in the hospital EHR for simple entries; knows where to look for physician notes and orders.
Medication awareness: recognizes common side effects and when to notify an RN (not a medication administrator unless trained).
Communication: clear, empathetic communication with patients and families, including delivering practical information calmly.
Time management: prioritizes tasks on busy shifts and triages personal workflow during high census.
Conflict de-escalation: calm voice, listening, redirecting to solutions during tense situations with patients or visitors.
Basic home-cooking skills optimized for cost and health: batch-cooking, freezer meals, seasoning to reduce salt.
Budgeting: tracking monthly bills, using a simple spreadsheet or notebook to allocate paychecks to essentials and savings.
Event organization: coordinates small church potlucks and donation drives (makes lists, secures items, delegates tasks).
Basic sewing and mending: can hem pants and sew on buttons.
Driving and route-finding for local appointments; comfortable with public transit as a backup.
Advocacy: can advocate for patients during discharge and with social work to address home barriers.

general: Keeps a small stack of cash separated for 'rainy day' emergencies.
Brings home-cooked meals to work for lunches to save money and control portions.
Attends church services most Sundays and volunteers for 1–2 community events per month.
Sends check-in calls to her mother every other evening.
Avoids long social media threads — prefers in-person conversations.
Counts grocery items aloud when budgeting to stick to coupons or discounts.
Saves small amounts from each paycheck and puts them into a labeled envelope for goals (car, rent, gas).
Sings quietly while preparing meals or folding laundry — often gospel or Motown.

morning: Wakes between 5:00–6:00 AM on workdays, depending on shift start time.
Drinks a cup of plain black coffee at home while checking the morning news on local radio.
Prepares a simple breakfast (oatmeal or peanut butter toast) and packs lunch.
Leaves early to allow extra time for metro delays, sometimes drops off a casserole at a neighbor's if they ask for help.
workday: Arrives to the floor 10–15 minutes early to receive handoff from outgoing CNA.
Checks patient assignments, helps with morning hygiene rounds, and completes assigned tasks in prioritized order.
Takes a 30-minute lunch when staffing allows; uses this time to call her mother or check church group messages.
Stretches breaks to relieve lower-back tightness after long lifting tasks and uses assist devices when available.
evening: After a day shift, stops by a discount grocery store for essentials and prepares a simple dinner.
Watches an episode of a favorite show or listens to gospel playlists to unwind.
Review bills and budget briefly before bed if payday is approaching.
Gets to bed around 10:00–11:30 PM depending on shift schedule; sleeps with a fan or white-noise to cover neighborhood sounds.
weekend: Often volunteers at a Saturday morning church outreach or helps organize donated food boxes.
Meets a small group of friends for brunch occasionally or attends a Hawks game with a cousin if tickets are affordable.
Does apartment chores, launders, and batches meals for the coming workweek.
Occasionally attends a continuing education class or visits the library for job resources.

physical_health: General: reasonably healthy but with low-level chronic issues influenced by work and diet.
Blood pressure: prehypertensive readings in past clinic checks; working to lower salt and manage weight.
Weight: overweight by BMI standards; actively trying to reduce weight through small dietary improvements and walking.
Chronic pain: intermittent lower-back stiffness attributed to lifting and long standing shifts; uses over-the-counter pain relievers and stretching.
Allergies: seasonal allergies (hay fever) treated with OTC antihistamines as needed.
Respiratory: mild, childhood asthma that is currently well-managed and rarely symptomatic.
Vaccinations: up-to-date on routine adult vaccines, received annual flu shots, vaccinated for COVID-19.
Dental: occasional dental sensitivity; visits dentist irregularly due to cost but goes for more serious issues.
Vision: wears reading glasses and gets vision checks at community clinic when needed.
Sleep: variable — often tired after night shifts; sleeps in short cycles when shift pattern is erratic.
mental_health: General: emotionally resilient but experiences anxiety about finances and the future; occasional low mood episodes tied to stressful months.
Access to care: limited access to steady therapy due to cost and schedule; occasionally uses church counseling services.
Coping strategies: leans on faith, prayer, walking groups, and talking with close friends; avoids heavy drinking or substance use.
Stressors: chronic stress from job demands, family caregiving responsibilities (helping elderly mother), and tight finances.
Substance use: does not use illicit drugs; drinks socially and rarely more than one drink; disapproves of community substance misuse and supports rehab options.
medical_history_summary: No children (nulliparous), no pregnancies to report.
Has had minor work-related injuries (sprained wrist) in the past, treated conservatively.
Regular screenings: occasional blood pressure checks at work health fair, basic bloodwork at community clinics when free programs are available.

relationships.name: Madeline Washington
relationships.description: Lives two neighborhoods over, retired school cafeteria worker. Close relationship; Shanice assists with appointments, groceries, and bills. Madeline is a central figure in Shanice's life — both supportive and gently critical.

relationships.name: Tyrone Washington
relationships.description: Works in municipal sanitation. They check in weekly, sometimes share vehicle maintenance tips; sometimes bickers about money.

relationships.name: Keisha Brown
relationships.relation: Close friend and fellow church volunteer
relationships.description: Friend for 15+ years. Keisha is the one Shanice calls about neighborhood rumors, recipes, and potluck planning. Provides emotional support and occasional rides.

relationships.name: Pastor Michael Lewis
relationships.description: Provides spiritual guidance and connects Shanice with outreach opportunities. Respects Shanice’s organizational energy and often invites her to lead small programs.

relationships.name: Work circle
relationships.description: Close professional ties with a cohort of RNs and CNAs; several coworkers socialize outside work and pitch in when someone needs coverage.

relationships.name: Dating status
relationships.description: Occasional dating via church socials and neighborhood events; cautious about relationships because of job demands and desire for financial stability. No long-term romantic commitments currently.

relationships.name: Extended family
relationships.description: Wider network of relatives across Atlanta; Shanice contributes to babysitting and tutoring younger relatives occasionally and is respected as a dependable aunt-figure.

other_facts: Born and raised in a south-Atlanta neighborhood; family has lived in the area for three generations.
Grew up going to the same church her grandmother attended; grandmother's recipes and faith shaped her identity.
First job at 16: dishwasher at a local diner — learned early how to stretch paycheck and work long hours.
Remembers a childhood summer when the neighborhood pooled money to fix a neighbor's roof after a storm; that memory shaped her belief in communal problem-solving.
Kept a shoebox of family recipes passed down from grandmother, including her prized sweet potato pie card.
Was the first in her immediate family to earn an associate degree.
Has a small, reliable 2008 Toyota Corolla with a dented bumper; keeps it well maintained and uses it for grocery runs and rides to church.
Once organized a coat drive through her church after a winter storm — collected 120 coats and coordinated distribution.
Has had one minor car accident (rear-ended in a parking lot) — no major injuries, but it was a financial strain.
Was furloughed for three weeks during the early months of the COVID-19 pandemic; experienced worry about bills and lost income.
Contracted mild COVID-19 in 2020, recovered fully; still occasionally volunteers for vaccine clinics to promote trust.
Has a small balcony garden with potted mint, basil, and a tomato plant that yields a few summer tomatoes.
Keeps a little notebook called 'Shanice's Lists' — grocery lists, bill tracking, recipes, and neighborhood contacts.
Is proud of teaching a Sunday school class for neighborhood children for several years; enjoys crafting lesson plans that are practical and fun.
Occasionally does side work preparing meals for elderly neighbors who cannot cook, charging a small fee that fits their budgets.
Knows how to make a basic Excel spreadsheet for budgeting, though prefers a handwritten ledger for everyday tracking.
Has one small outstanding collection of medical debt from an ambulatory procedure years ago that she pays down slowly.
Once missed a promotion to LPN due to scheduling conflicts between required classes and her unpredictable shift work — still considers returning to school.
Very close to her Aunt Lorraine who taught her to sew and who now lives in the same city; they share recipes and gossip over phone every Sunday.
Has a favorite hymnal song — 'Precious Lord, Take My Hand' — which she sings to calm herself during stressful shifts.
Knows the names of many patients in the neighborhood hospital; when someone new comes in, she often recognizes them from community events.
Participated in a neighborhood beautification day — painted a mural on a community center wall with other volunteers.
Once received an award from the hospital for 'Outstanding Team Player' after helping coordinate patient transfers during a mass-admission weekend.
Takes pride in small holiday traditions: baking pies for neighbors and exchanging plates of food rather than commercial gifts.
Has a modest emergency fund — about $2,000 in a savings account — built slowly over time and considered precious.
Does not drink heavily and avoids drugs; has friends and family who struggled with addiction which informed her compassionate stance on rehab and recovery.
Has an active Facebook group for her block where residents post safety notices, lost pets, and free items — she moderates occasionally.
Volunteers once a month at a neighborhood free clinic doing blood pressure checks and health education under nurse supervision.
Enjoys Saturday morning flea markets to find bargain tableware or cookbooks.
Has an old Polaroid camera she uses to take candid shots at potlucks and church events; prints a few for a corkboard at home.
Has a mild fear of deep water; avoids open-water swimming but will wade at supervised pools with lifeguards present.
